articles.title: UN: World Leaders Should Commit to Human Rights, International Justice
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              The United Nations General Assembly Hall in New York City, New York, US, April 21, 2025.
                    © 2025 UN Photo/Loey Felipe
          
    


  
(New York) – World leaders gathering at the United Nations General Assembly from September 22-30 should commit to protecting the UN from powerful governments seeking to defund and undermine the organization’s capacity to promote human rights and international justice, Human Rights Watch said.On the eve of the General Assembly’s annual general debate, world leaders will hold a summit on the situation in Palestine, which French President Emmanuel Macron and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman are expected to preside over. “Human rights and the UN itself are in the crosshairs of powerful governments to an unprecedented extent,” said Federico Borello, interim executive director of Human Rights Watch. “World leaders should pledge action to ensure the world body has the resources and political support it needs to carry out its lifesaving human rights and humanitarian work around the world – in Gaza, Ukraine, Sudan, Haiti, and elsewhere people are in need.”Governments should also take action to stop Israel’s escalating atrocities against Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, Human Rights Watch said. They should condemn and take steps to counter US sanctions against International Criminal Court (ICC) officials, prominent Palestinian organizations, and a UN expert. They should rally behind institutions like the ICC, which is combating impunity for war crimes and other atrocities in Myanmar, Israel/Palestine, Sudan, Ukraine, and elsewhere around the globe.World leaders should use the September 22 Palestine conference to publicly commit to action aimed at ending decades of impunity for Israeli authorities’ violations of international humanitarian and human rights law against Palestinians. This summit, a response to the landmark July 2024 advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian Territory, is a continuation of a high-level meeting in July. That ICJ advisory opinion determined that Israel’s decades-long occupation is unlawful,  breaches Palestinians’ right to self-determination, and is marked by serious abuses, including apartheid. At the September 22 conference, France, the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and others have said they would recognize a Palestinian state. However, those declarations risk being empty gestures unless states commit to concrete actions to stop Israel’s extermination of Palestinians and expansion of unlawful settlements. Governments should suspend arms transfers to Israel, ban trade with illegal settlements, and impose targeted sanctions on Israeli officials responsible for ongoing crimes against Palestinians, including crimes against humanity and acts of genocide, Human Rights Watch said. States should also press Hamas and Palestinian armed groups to release all civilian hostages.The UN is in the throes of an existential financial crisis, largely due to the United States’ refusal to pay its assessed contributions – which countries are obligated to pay – and its cancellation of virtually all US voluntary funding for myriad UN agencies and bodies. This is undermining UN humanitarian work, as well as human rights investigations in Ukraine, Russia, Sudan, Syria, Israel/Palestine, Democratic Republic of Congo, Afghanistan, Myanmar, North Korea, and elsewhere. The US is not alone in defaulting on its financial obligations to the UN. China, the UN’s second biggest contributor, has been delaying its payments to the organization’s regular budget and peacekeeping operations. Many other governmentsare also in arrears. Wealthy governments in the European Union, UK, Germany, France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Sweden, and others have followed the US decision to gut its foreign aid programs by further reducing their own foreign aid budgets, exacerbating the UN’s financial troubles. Governments that care about human rights should pay their assessed contributions in full and on time and increase voluntary contributions to the UN, prioritizing programs that protect human rights and save lives. In 2023, the US contributed nearly $13 billion in assessed and voluntary contributions to the UN. That figure has dropped to nearly zero this year after Trump ordered a “review” of US contributions to the UN. It remains unclear if, when, and to what extent the US might resume UN funding. The UN leadership should seek ways to reduce costs while avoiding across-the-board cuts that would disproportionately impact human rights work, which is already chronically underfunded. As the UN leadership presses ahead with a package of cost-cutting proposals as part of its “UN80” initiative, it should ensure that independent investigations of human rights abuses have the necessary resources to continue.  “UN monitoring and investigations can deter abusive governments from committing atrocities against civilians,” said Borello. “Powerful governments seeking to undermine the UN’s human rights and humanitarian programs should be condemned, not emulated. The lives of millions of people around the world depend on it.”Leaders should press for meaningful action to address dire crises in Sudan and Haiti. In Sudan, civilians are facing famine, sexual violence, and other atrocities. In Haiti, criminal groups are expanding their control, escalating killings and sexual violence, including gang rape, forcing millions into displacement and facing acute food insecurity. Meanwhile, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has declined to endorse calls from human rights defenders and member states to deploy physical protection missions to Sudan and Haiti.On February 6, Trump issued an executive order that authorizes asset freezes and entry bans on ICC officials and others supporting the court’s work. The US government has so far imposed sanctions on the court’s prosecutor, his two deputies, six judges, the UN special rapporteur for the Occupied Palestinian Territory Francesca Albanese, as well as three leading Palestinian civil society organizations. These sanctions are a blatant attack on the rule of law and the international justice system. They aim primarily to thwart the ICC's ongoing Palestine investigation, including the court’s pending arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant for crimes against humanity and war crimes in Gaza. UN member states should affirm their support for the ICC’s global mandate and civil society’s critical work, and call on the US government to cancel the sanctions program. Member states should also commit to concrete steps to protect the court from these sanctions, including through legislation like the EU Blocking Statute, which aims to shield European companies from the effects of extraterritorial sanctions.  Member states should further commit to international justice by implementing all of the ICJ’s advisory opinions, including the court’s July opinion calling climate change an existential threat to the planet and arguing that states’ failure to protect the climate triggers legal consequences.Delegates should urge member states to press ahead with negotiations on an international treaty to prevent and punish crimes against humanity. The treaty will fill a gap in international law that contributes to impunity for egregious acts of murder, torture, enforced disappearance, sexual violence, and persecution, among others, inflicted on civilians around the world.Horrific, systematic abuses the Taliban have continued committing against women and girls in Afghanistan since retaking power in 2021 exemplify why gender apartheid as a crime against humanity should be included in any eventual treaty on crimes against humanity, Human Rights Watch said. “The UN and international human rights system are being put to the test,” said Borello. “To be on the right side of history, it’s crucial to push back against powerful governments trying to undermine international norms and demolish avenues for accountability.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image The United Nations General Assembly Hall in New York City, New York, US, April 21, 2025. © 2025 UN Photo/Loey Felipe

(New York) – World leaders gathering at the United Nations General Assembly from September 22-30 should commit to protecting the UN from powerful governments seeking to defund and undermine the organization’s capacity to promote human rights and international justice, Human Rights Watch said.

On the eve of the General Assembly’s annual general debate, world leaders will hold a summit on the situation in Palestine, which French President Emmanuel Macron and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman are expected to preside over.

“Human rights and the UN itself are in the crosshairs of powerful governments to an unprecedented extent,” said Federico Borello, interim executive director of Human Rights Watch. “World leaders should pledge action to ensure the world body has the resources and political support it needs to carry out its lifesaving human rights and humanitarian work around the world – in Gaza, Ukraine, Sudan, Haiti, and elsewhere people are in need.”

Governments should also take action to stop Israel’s escalating atrocities against Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, Human Rights Watch said. They should condemn and take steps to counter US sanctions against International Criminal Court (ICC) officials, prominent Palestinian organizations, and a UN expert. They should rally behind institutions like the ICC, which is combating impunity for war crimes and other atrocities in Myanmar, Israel/Palestine, Sudan, Ukraine, and elsewhere around the globe.

World leaders should use the September 22 Palestine conference to publicly commit to action aimed at ending decades of impunity for Israeli authorities’ violations of international humanitarian and human rights law against Palestinians. This summit, a response to the landmark July 2024 advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian Territory, is a continuation of a high-level meeting in July.

That ICJ advisory opinion determined that Israel’s decades-long occupation is unlawful, breaches Palestinians’ right to self-determination, and is marked by serious abuses, including apartheid. At the September 22 conference, France, the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and others have said they would recognize a Palestinian state.

However, those declarations risk being empty gestures unless states commit to concrete actions to stop Israel’s extermination of Palestinians and expansion of unlawful settlements. Governments should suspend arms transfers to Israel, ban trade with illegal settlements, and impose targeted sanctions on Israeli officials responsible for ongoing crimes against Palestinians, including crimes against humanity and acts of genocide, Human Rights Watch said. States should also press Hamas and Palestinian armed groups to release all civilian hostages.

The UN is in the throes of an existential financial crisis, largely due to the United States’ refusal to pay its assessed contributions – which countries are obligated to pay – and its cancellation of virtually all US voluntary funding for myriad UN agencies and bodies. This is undermining UN humanitarian work, as well as human rights investigations in Ukraine, Russia, Sudan, Syria, Israel/Palestine, Democratic Republic of Congo, Afghanistan, Myanmar, North Korea, and elsewhere.

The US is not alone in defaulting on its financial obligations to the UN. China, the UN’s second biggest contributor, has been delaying its payments to the organization’s regular budget and peacekeeping operations. Many other governmentsare also in arrears. Wealthy governments in the European Union, UK, Germany, France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Sweden, and others have followed the US decision to gut its foreign aid programs by further reducing their own foreign aid budgets, exacerbating the UN’s financial troubles.

Governments that care about human rights should pay their assessed contributions in full and on time and increase voluntary contributions to the UN, prioritizing programs that protect human rights and save lives.

In 2023, the US contributed nearly $13 billion in assessed and voluntary contributions to the UN. That figure has dropped to nearly zero this year after Trump ordered a “review” of US contributions to the UN. It remains unclear if, when, and to what extent the US might resume UN funding.

The UN leadership should seek ways to reduce costs while avoiding across-the-board cuts that would disproportionately impact human rights work, which is already chronically underfunded. As the UN leadership presses ahead with a package of cost-cutting proposals as part of its “UN80” initiative, it should ensure that independent investigations of human rights abuses have the necessary resources to continue.

“UN monitoring and investigations can deter abusive governments from committing atrocities against civilians,” said Borello. “Powerful governments seeking to undermine the UN’s human rights and humanitarian programs should be condemned, not emulated. The lives of millions of people around the world depend on it.”

Leaders should press for meaningful action to address dire crises in Sudan and Haiti. In Sudan, civilians are facing famine, sexual violence, and other atrocities. In Haiti, criminal groups are expanding their control, escalating killings and sexual violence, including gang rape, forcing millions into displacement and facing acute food insecurity. Meanwhile, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres has declined to endorse calls from human rights defenders and member states to deploy physical protection missions to Sudan and Haiti.

On February 6, Trump issued an executive order that authorizes asset freezes and entry bans on ICC officials and others supporting the court’s work. The US government has so far imposed sanctions on the court’s prosecutor, his two deputies, six judges, the UN special rapporteur for the Occupied Palestinian Territory Francesca Albanese, as well as three leading Palestinian civil society organizations. These sanctions are a blatant attack on the rule of law and the international justice system. They aim primarily to thwart the ICC's ongoing Palestine investigation, including the court’s pending arrest warrants for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant for crimes against humanity and war crimes in Gaza.

UN member states should affirm their support for the ICC’s global mandate and civil society’s critical work, and call on the US government to cancel the sanctions program. Member states should also commit to concrete steps to protect the court from these sanctions, including through legislation like the EU Blocking Statute, which aims to shield European companies from the effects of extraterritorial sanctions.

Member states should further commit to international justice by implementing all of the ICJ’s advisory opinions, including the court’s July opinion calling climate change an existential threat to the planet and arguing that states’ failure to protect the climate triggers legal consequences.

Delegates should urge member states to press ahead with negotiations on an international treaty to prevent and punish crimes against humanity. The treaty will fill a gap in international law that contributes to impunity for egregious acts of murder, torture, enforced disappearance, sexual violence, and persecution, among others, inflicted on civilians around the world.

Horrific, systematic abuses the Taliban have continued committing against women and girls in Afghanistan since retaking power in 2021 exemplify why gender apartheid as a crime against humanity should be included in any eventual treaty on crimes against humanity, Human Rights Watch said.

“The UN and international human rights system are being put to the test,” said Borello. “To be on the right side of history, it’s crucial to push back against powerful governments trying to undermine international norms and demolish avenues for accountability.”

It addresses broad, meaningful issues such as combating impunity for war crimes, supporting the International Criminal Court, and pushing for concrete actions to end human rights abuses in multiple conflict zones. The story focuses on a major global event (UN General Assembly) and contains detailed context about the challenges and necessary commitments, making it a substantive and impactful good news story in the human rights domain.
articles.personality_title: World leaders urged to strengthen UN support for human rights and justice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Each year, world leaders meet at the United Nations General Assembly to discuss global issues. In 2025, this meeting comes at a time when the UN faces financial challenges and pressure from some powerful countries that want to weaken its role in protecting human rights and enforcing international justice.

**What happened** – Ahead of the September 22-30 UN General Assembly, Human Rights Watch called on leaders to protect the UN’s ability to promote human rights worldwide. A special summit on Palestine is planned, led by French President Emmanuel Macron and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. The summit follows a 2024 International Court of Justice ruling that Israel’s long occupation of Palestinian territories is illegal and involves serious abuses.

**Impact** – This moment is important because it urges countries to take real actions, like stopping arms sales to Israel and supporting the International Criminal Court (ICC), which investigates war crimes in places like Palestine, Sudan, and Ukraine. The UN’s financial crisis, worsened by the US and other countries delaying payments, threatens vital human rights work. If leaders respond, it could help save lives and hold those responsible for abuses accountable.

**What's next step** – Leaders are expected to make promises at the Palestine summit and the General Assembly to back the UN and the ICC, including stopping illegal settlements and supporting justice efforts. They also need to address crises in Sudan and Haiti and work on a new treaty to punish crimes against humanity. The UN will also try to cut costs wisely to keep important investigations running.

**One-sentence takeaway** – World leaders have a chance to strengthen the UN’s role in protecting human rights and justice by committing funds and actions during the 2025 General Assembly and Palestine summit.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les dirigeants mondiaux appelés à renforcer le soutien à l’ONU pour les droits humains et la justice
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, les dirigeants mondiaux se réunissent à l’Assemblée générale des Nations Unies pour discuter des problèmes mondiaux. En 2025, cette réunion a lieu alors que l’ONU fait face à des difficultés financières et à des pressions de certains pays puissants qui veulent affaiblir son rôle dans la protection des droits humains et la justice internationale.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Avant l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU du 22 au 30 septembre, Human Rights Watch a appelé les dirigeants à protéger la capacité de l’ONU à promouvoir les droits humains dans le monde. Un sommet spécial sur la Palestine est prévu, présidé par le président français Emmanuel Macron et le prince héritier saoudien Mohammed ben Salmane. Ce sommet fait suite à une décision de 2024 de la Cour internationale de Justice qui juge illégale l’occupation israélienne des territoires palestiniens et dénonce de graves violations.

**Impact** – Ce moment est important car il encourage les pays à agir concrètement, comme arrêter les ventes d’armes à Israël et soutenir la Cour pénale internationale (CPI), qui enquête sur des crimes de guerre en Palestine, au Soudan et en Ukraine. La crise financière de l’ONU, aggravée par le retard de paiement des États-Unis et d’autres pays, menace des actions vitales pour les droits humains. Une réponse forte pourrait sauver des vies et rendre justice.

**Prochaine étape** – Les dirigeants devraient prendre des engagements lors du sommet sur la Palestine et de l’Assemblée générale pour soutenir l’ONU et la CPI, notamment en arrêtant les colonies illégales et en appuyant les efforts de justice. Ils doivent aussi agir face aux crises au Soudan et en Haïti et avancer sur un nouveau traité contre les crimes contre l’humanité. L’ONU cherchera aussi à réduire ses coûts sans sacrifier les enquêtes importantes.

**Message clé en une phrase** – Les dirigeants mondiaux ont l’occasion de renforcer le rôle de l’ONU dans la protection des droits humains et de la justice en s’engageant financièrement et politiquement lors de l’Assemblée générale 2025 et du sommet sur la Palestine.
articles.personality_title_es: Líderes mundiales instados a fortalecer el apoyo de la ONU a los derechos humanos y la justicia
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, los líderes mundiales se reúnen en la Asamblea General de las Naciones Unidas para hablar sobre problemas globales. En 2025, esta reunión ocurre en un momento en que la ONU enfrenta problemas financieros y presiones de algunos países poderosos que quieren debilitar su papel en la protección de los derechos humanos y la justicia internacional.

**Qué pasó** – Antes de la Asamblea General de la ONU del 22 al 30 de septiembre, Human Rights Watch pidió a los líderes que protejan la capacidad de la ONU para promover los derechos humanos en todo el mundo. Se planeó una cumbre especial sobre Palestina, presidida por el presidente francés Emmanuel Macron y el príncipe heredero saudí Mohammed bin Salman. Esta cumbre sigue a una decisión de 2024 de la Corte Internacional de Justicia que declaró ilegal la ocupación israelí de los territorios palestinos y señaló graves abusos.

**Impacto** – Este momento es importante porque anima a los países a tomar acciones concretas, como detener la venta de armas a Israel y apoyar a la Corte Penal Internacional (CPI), que investiga crímenes de guerra en Palestina, Sudán y Ucrania. La crisis financiera de la ONU, agravada por el retraso en los pagos de Estados Unidos y otros países, amenaza trabajos vitales de derechos humanos. Una respuesta firme podría salvar vidas y hacer justicia.

**Próximo paso** – Se espera que los líderes hagan compromisos en la cumbre sobre Palestina y en la Asamblea General para apoyar a la ONU y a la CPI, incluyendo detener los asentamientos ilegales y respaldar los esfuerzos de justicia. También deben actuar sobre las crisis en Sudán y Haití y avanzar en un nuevo tratado para castigar crímenes contra la humanidad. La ONU buscará reducir costos sin afectar las investigaciones importantes.

**Frase clave** – Los líderes mundiales tienen la oportunidad de fortalecer el papel de la ONU en la protección de los derechos humanos y la justicia comprometiendo fondos y acciones durante la Asamblea General 2025 y la cumbre sobre Palestina.

articles.title: Venezuelan migrants drive economic gains in Ecuador but face persistent vulnerabilities
articles.summary: Venezuelan migrants in Ecuador contribute an estimated $900 million each year to the country’s economy, yet many remain trapped in informal work and vulnerable conditions, according to a new study by the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM).
articles.content:
“The evidence is clear: when migrants have access to rights and opportunities, they contribute substantially to the societies that host them,” said Kristina Mejo, the head of the agency in Ecuador.

Venezuelans currently number around 441,000 in Ecuador, with households paying nearly $47 million in taxes annually.

Their contributions have been enabled by public policies that streamlined documentation processes, expanded access to formal jobs, social security and financial services and recognised academic degrees.

These steps have boosted productivity while helping integrate migrants into the system.

Tweet URL

Barriers and inequities

However, despite these gains, significant challenges remain.

Most Venezuelans are young – over 70 per cent are between 18 and 39 – yet around two-thirds work in the informal sector. Only 30 per cent are employed in their field of expertise.

Women, in particular face even steeper hurdles: nearly 70 per cent work informally and many earn below the minimum wage.

Migration and remittances worldwide

The study comes as global remittances – money sent home by migrant workers – continue to rise.

IOM’s 2024 World Migration Report shows transfers increasing from $128 billion in 2000 to $831 billion in 2022, underscoring migration’s growing economic weight.

High-income countries, led by the United States, are the primary sources. In 2022, the US alone sent $79 billion abroad, supporting families and strengthening global financial ties.

Similarly, migrants in Saudi Arabia sent home $39.4 billion, followed by those in Switzerland ($31.9 billion) and Germany ($25.6 billion).

India, Mexico, China, the Philippines and Egypt were (in descending order) the top five remittance recipient countries, with India well above the rest.

Inward remittances in India exceeded $111 billion, the first country to reach and even exceed $100 billion.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the positive economic contributions of Venezuelan migrants in Ecuador enabled by inclusive public policies that improve migrants' access to rights and formal employment. It also addresses ongoing challenges, providing a substantive and meaningful discussion on migration's societal impact, which is significant for public understanding and policy development.
articles.personality_title: Venezuelan migrants boost Ecuador’s economy while facing work challenges
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 441,000 Venezuelan migrants live in Ecuador. They arrived seeking better opportunities after economic troubles in Venezuela. The Ecuadorian government has introduced policies to help migrants work legally and access services.

**What happened** – A new study by the United Nations’ International Organization for Migration (IOM) found that Venezuelan migrants contribute about $900 million every year to Ecuador’s economy. They also pay nearly $47 million in taxes. These gains come from easier paperwork, job access, and recognition of their education.

**Impact** – This shows that when migrants can work formally and access rights, they help the country’s economy grow. However, many still work informal jobs without contracts or benefits. Young migrants make up most of the group, but only 30% work in jobs matching their skills. Women face even harder conditions, with many earning less than the minimum wage.

**What’s next step** – To improve the situation, Ecuador may need to expand policies that support fair work and reduce informal employment. Helping migrants find jobs that match their skills could also boost the economy further and improve lives.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Venezuelan migrants significantly support Ecuador’s economy, but more work is needed to ensure fair and formal job opportunities for all.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les migrants vénézuéliens stimulent l'économie de l'Équateur malgré des défis au travail
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Environ 441 000 migrants vénézuéliens vivent en Équateur. Ils sont arrivés en quête de meilleures opportunités après des difficultés économiques au Venezuela. Le gouvernement équatorien a mis en place des politiques pour aider les migrants à travailler légalement et accéder aux services.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Une nouvelle étude de l’Organisation internationale pour les migrations (OIM) des Nations Unies a révélé que les migrants vénézuéliens contribuent environ 900 millions de dollars chaque année à l’économie équatorienne. Ils paient aussi près de 47 millions de dollars en impôts. Ces progrès résultent de la simplification des démarches, de l’accès à l’emploi et de la reconnaissance de leurs diplômes.

**Impact** – Cela montre que lorsque les migrants peuvent travailler officiellement et bénéficier de droits, ils aident à faire croître l’économie du pays. Pourtant, beaucoup travaillent encore dans l’informel, sans contrat ni avantages. Les jeunes migrants représentent la majorité, mais seulement 30 % exercent un métier correspondant à leurs compétences. Les femmes rencontrent des conditions encore plus difficiles, beaucoup gagnant moins que le salaire minimum.

**Prochaine étape** – Pour améliorer la situation, l’Équateur pourrait renforcer les politiques favorisant un travail équitable et réduire l’emploi informel. Aider les migrants à trouver des emplois adaptés à leurs compétences pourrait aussi stimuler davantage l’économie et améliorer les conditions de vie.

**Une phrase clé** – Les migrants vénézuéliens soutiennent fortement l’économie équatorienne, mais davantage d’efforts sont nécessaires pour garantir des emplois formels et justes pour tous.
articles.personality_title_es: Los migrantes venezolanos impulsan la economía de Ecuador pese a desafíos laborales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Alrededor de 441,000 migrantes venezolanos viven en Ecuador. Llegaron buscando mejores oportunidades tras problemas económicos en Venezuela. El gobierno ecuatoriano ha implementado políticas para facilitar que los migrantes trabajen legalmente y accedan a servicios.

**Qué pasó** – Un nuevo estudio de la Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM) de la ONU encontró que los migrantes venezolanos aportan cerca de 900 millones de dólares cada año a la economía ecuatoriana. También pagan casi 47 millones en impuestos. Estos avances se deben a trámites simplificados, acceso a empleo y reconocimiento de sus títulos.

**Impacto** – Esto demuestra que cuando los migrantes pueden trabajar formalmente y tener derechos, ayudan a crecer la economía del país. Sin embargo, muchos aún trabajan en el sector informal, sin contratos ni beneficios. La mayoría son jóvenes, pero solo el 30 % trabaja en empleos relacionados con sus habilidades. Las mujeres enfrentan condiciones aún más difíciles, con muchas ganando menos que el salario mínimo.

**Próximo paso** – Para mejorar la situación, Ecuador podría ampliar políticas que apoyen el trabajo justo y reduzcan el empleo informal. Ayudar a los migrantes a conseguir empleos acordes a sus habilidades podría fortalecer aún más la economía y mejorar sus vidas.

**Una frase clave** – Los migrantes venezolanos aportan mucho a la economía de Ecuador, pero se necesita avanzar para garantizar empleos formales y justos para todos.

articles.title: Elif Shafak: Fiction as a bridge across divides in a fractured world
articles.summary: In this episode of arts24, Eve Jackson sits down with one of the most celebrated British-Turkish novelists of our time, Elif Shafak. With over 20 books translated into more than 50 languages, Shafak believes fiction remains one of the last truly democratic spaces, where stories can build empathy, challenge polarisation and create connections across cultures. Her latest novel, "There Are Rivers in the Sky", takes readers on a sweeping journey through history and geography, tracing a single drop of water from ancient Mesopotamia to modern-day Iraq, against the urgent backdrop of climate crisis and cultural loss.
articles.content:

Reading time 1 min

In this episode of arts24, Eve Jackson sits down with one of the most celebrated British-Turkish novelists of our time, Elif Shafak. With over 20 books translated into more than 50 languages, Shafak believes fiction remains one of the last truly democratic spaces, where stories can build empathy, challenge polarisation and create connections across cultures. Her latest novel, "There Are Rivers in the Sky", takes readers on a sweeping journey through history and geography, tracing a single drop of water from ancient Mesopotamia to modern-day Iraq, against the urgent backdrop of climate crisis and cultural loss.

Elif discusses how nature becomes a powerful storyteller in her work, why she chose to give voice to the Yazidi community, and what it means to write as an exile grappling with censorship, identity and the fight for artistic freedom.

Beyond her novels, Elif Shafak is a passionate public intellectual, speaking out on women’s rights, democracy and minority voices. She shares how literature can foster empathy across gender, class and culture, and reflects on the role of the writer in today’s divided world.

Join us for a deep and inspiring conversation with a writer who sees stories as a way to heal, connect and transform.
articles.source: News and stories on CULTURE, movies, music, literature - France 24
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Elif Shafak's use of fiction as a democratic space to build empathy, challenge polarization, and connect cultures, addressing significant societal issues such as minority voices, women's rights, and artistic freedom. This has broad positive impact by promoting understanding and social cohesion in a divided world, supported by detailed context about her work and advocacy.
articles.personality_title: Elif Shafak uses fiction to connect cultures and inspire empathy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Elif Shafak is a British-Turkish novelist known for her many books translated into over 50 languages. She believes stories and fiction can help people understand each other better and bring different cultures closer.

**What happened** – In a recent interview on arts24, Shafak talked about her new novel, "There Are Rivers in the Sky." The book follows a single drop of water from ancient Mesopotamia to modern Iraq, highlighting issues like climate change and cultural loss. She also discussed how she gives a voice to the Yazidi community and writes about her own experiences with exile and censorship.

**Impact** – Shafak’s work shows how stories can be a space where anyone can share their experiences and learn about others. This helps reduce divisions between people by building empathy and understanding across different backgrounds. Her focus on women’s rights, democracy, and minority voices adds important perspectives often missing in many conversations.

**What's next step** – Shafak will continue to write and speak publicly about social issues, using her novels and talks to inspire more open discussions about identity, freedom, and cooperation in a world that often feels divided.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Elif Shafak uses fiction to bridge cultural divides and promote empathy by sharing powerful stories about history, nature, and human rights.
articles.personality_title_fr: Elif Shafak utilise la fiction pour rapprocher les cultures et inspirer l'empathie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Elif Shafak est une romancière britannique-turque dont les nombreux livres ont été traduits en plus de 50 langues. Elle pense que les histoires et la fiction aident les gens à mieux se comprendre et à rapprocher différentes cultures.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Lors d'une récente interview sur arts24, Shafak a parlé de son nouveau roman, « Il y a des rivières dans le ciel ». Le livre suit une goutte d'eau unique de la Mésopotamie ancienne à l'Irak moderne, en soulignant des problèmes comme le changement climatique et la perte culturelle. Elle a aussi évoqué comment elle donne une voix à la communauté yézidie et écrit sur ses propres expériences d'exil et de censure.

**Impact** – Le travail de Shafak montre que les histoires peuvent être un espace où chacun peut partager ses expériences et découvrir celles des autres. Cela aide à réduire les divisions entre les gens en développant l'empathie et la compréhension entre différents milieux. Son attention aux droits des femmes, à la démocratie et aux voix des minorités apporte des perspectives importantes souvent absentes dans de nombreuses discussions.

**Prochaine étape** – Shafak continuera à écrire et à s'exprimer publiquement sur les questions sociales, en utilisant ses romans et ses interventions pour encourager des discussions plus ouvertes sur l'identité, la liberté et la coopération dans un monde souvent divisé.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Elif Shafak utilise la fiction pour construire des ponts entre les cultures et promouvoir l'empathie grâce à des histoires puissantes sur l'histoire, la nature et les droits humains.
articles.personality_title_es: Elif Shafak usa la ficción para conectar culturas e inspirar empatía
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Elif Shafak es una novelista británico-turca con muchos libros traducidos a más de 50 idiomas. Cree que las historias y la ficción ayudan a que las personas se entiendan mejor y acerquen diferentes culturas.

**Qué pasó** – En una entrevista reciente en arts24, Shafak habló sobre su nueva novela, "Hay ríos en el cielo". El libro sigue una gota de agua desde la antigua Mesopotamia hasta el Irak moderno, destacando temas como el cambio climático y la pérdida cultural. También habló sobre cómo da voz a la comunidad yazidí y escribe sobre sus propias experiencias con el exilio y la censura.

**Impacto** – El trabajo de Shafak muestra cómo las historias pueden ser un espacio donde cualquiera puede compartir sus experiencias y aprender sobre otras personas. Esto ayuda a reducir las divisiones entre las personas al construir empatía y comprensión entre diferentes orígenes. Su enfoque en los derechos de las mujeres, la democracia y las voces minoritarias añade perspectivas importantes que a menudo faltan en muchas conversaciones.

**Próximo paso** – Shafak seguirá escribiendo y hablando públicamente sobre temas sociales, usando sus novelas y charlas para inspirar discusiones más abiertas sobre identidad, libertad y cooperación en un mundo que a menudo se siente dividido.

**Resumen en una frase** – Elif Shafak usa la ficción para unir culturas y promover la empatía contando historias poderosas sobre historia, naturaleza y derechos humanos.
